steps.title: Apply ice for 10–15 minutes, at least 4 times per day.
steps.content: Apply ice for 10–15 minutes, at least 4 times per day. Reduce the frequency as required over the next 48 hours. You can also use a wet tea towel, ice pack, or reusable cold therapy and compression wrap . Don’t apply ice directly against your skin. [2] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Once the acute pain stage has passed, try applying a heat pack wrapped in a towel for 15 to 20 minutes at a time. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Take NSAIDs to reduce pain and inflammation.
steps.content: Take NSAIDs to reduce pain and inflammation. [4] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source NSAIDs are non-steroidal anti-inflammatories like ibuprofen, naproxen, and aspirin. [5] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Painkillers or muscle relaxers like acetaminophen and cyclobenzaprine won’t be useful because they don’t treat inflammation. [6] X Research source Ask your physician about using NSAIDs if you have hypertension, asthma, a history of kidney or liver disease or ulcer, or are older than 65. Consult your doctor if you are on any other medications, as NSAIDs can impact the effects of other medications.

steps.title: Stop overusing the tendons until you’re completely pain-free.
steps.content: Stop overusing the tendons until you’re completely pain-free. This can take several days to a couple of months. Identify what motions are creating the problem (such as running) and take a break from that activity as best you can. If the tendonitis flares up at work, see if your employer will let you switch to a different activity. [7] X Research source Since this injury usually occurs from overuse, trying to resume your previous level of activity even when your pain seems lessened can worsen your injury and increase the time it needs to fully heal. Resume activities gradually and under the guidance of a health professional. [8] X Research source If your tendonitis becomes chronic, it can lead to tendinosis, which is a non-inflammatory degeneration of the tendon that takes 3–9 months to heal. [9] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Begin rehabilitation once you can walk or flex your hands without pain.
steps.content: Begin rehabilitation once you can walk or flex your hands without pain. Do stretching exercises like toe raises if you’re experiencing foot tendonitis. If you have hand tendinitis, try placing your palms together in front of your face, then raising your elbows out and upwards while keeping your hands still. Hold for 15 seconds and repeat 3 times. [10] X Research source To stretch your feet, kneel down with your feet pointing backwards underneath your bottom and flatten your ankles towards the floor. Tight calves can contribute to foot tendonitis. [11] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Stretch your calves by standing on a step with the heel hanging off the back of the step and dropping your heel down. Do this no more than 3 times for 30 seconds each. [12] X Research source Once your foot tendonitis improves, loop a resistance band over your toes and pull down gently on the band while extending your toes against the resistance. Repeat 10-15 times for 1-3 sets to strengthen your foot’s extensor muscles. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Wear appropriate footwear correctly if suffering from foot tendonitis.
steps.content: Wear appropriate footwear correctly if suffering from foot tendonitis. Your shoes must fit and cannot be laced too tightly. [14] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Try a different lacing pattern by tying your knot at the side or skipping one of the lacing holes near the area causing you pain. This will place pressure on different spots of your foot. [15] X Research source Orthotics , or inserts and insoles for your shoes, can pad and support your foot and take away some stress from your tendons. [16] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source A podiatrist can help fit orthotics correctly for you. Running shoes should be replaced after approximately 300 miles (480 km) of running. After this, the midsole starts to degrade. [17] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Identify the location and nature of your pain.
steps.content: Identify the location and nature of your pain. Tendinopathy presents as pain on the top of the foot, usually described as aching, or an inability to fully extend one of your fingers. [18] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If the tendonitis is on your hand, your finger may be jammed, your hand may feel numb or weak, or there may be a cut on the back of your hand or fingers. [19] X Research source Diffuse swelling or mild bruising along the top of the foot may be present. Curling your toes may hurt because it stretches the tendons on the top of your foot.

steps.title: Ask your doctor for a diagnosis and treatment options.
steps.content: Ask your doctor for a diagnosis and treatment options. Doctors can assess whether you have tendonitis and how severe it is, sometimes by using an ultrasound or MRI. They can also refer you to physical therapy, splint your finger, or for very serious cases notify you that you may need surgery. [20] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Your doctor can also prescribe you over-the-counter NSAIDs.

steps.title: Follow your doctor’s instructions if given finger splints or stitches.
steps.content: Follow your doctor’s instructions if given finger splints or stitches. Jamming injuries are typically treated with splints or pins which then hold the tendon in place. They should be worn until the tendon is healed, which usually takes 8–12 weeks. [21] X Research source Make sure your splint is not so tight that it cuts off blood flow. [22] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Contact your doctor if your stitches come apart or you feel sudden numbness around the wound. [23] X Research source

steps.title: Inquire about anti-inflammatory and pain-relieving creams or gels.
steps.content: Inquire about anti-inflammatory and pain-relieving creams or gels. These can be used as an alternative to oral NSAIDs. Because the drugs stay where they are applied, there will be less build-up of the drugs in your blood and more remote tissues over time. This is best if you would otherwise be taking oral NSAIDs for more than 3 weeks. [24] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Common side effects may include flu-like symptoms and a rash or burning sensation at the application site. Generally, the cream or gel must be rubbed on the appropriate area 2–4 times a day.

steps.title: Ask your physician about steroid injections for tendonitis on your feet.
steps.content: Ask your physician about steroid injections for tendonitis on your feet. These can reduce inflammation but will temporarily weaken your tendons. [25] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Steroid injections are useful for short-term pain relief and increased mobility, but are not necessarily a long-term solution. In some rare cases, they could even cause your weakened tendon to tear. If you use blood thinners or certain dietary supplements, you may need to stop taking them for several days to reduce the risk of bleeding or bruising. In some cases, your doctor may decide against injections altogether. [26] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Injections can take a few hours to a few days to begin relieving pain. [27] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source After an injection, you may experience pain and discomfort around the injection site for a few days. [28] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: Try physical therapy if your doctor recommends it.
steps.content: Try physical therapy if your doctor recommends it. Physical therapists will give you stretches and strengthening exercises tailored to your injury, be it to your hands or feet. [29] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Some can also use therapeutic ultrasounds or infrared light waves to decrease inflammation and encourage healing. [30] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source
